text: so emarketer was founded in 1996 and
we're the world's leading provider of

said a few years ago we decided to
actually move from coalos to Azure and
we used several Azure products one of

offering called cloud services horrible
name by the way they work really well
for us at the time
unfortunately development sort of
stopped on that and we haven't seen new
features in actually years and so our
Enterprise Agreement
ended and we decided to look elsewhere
and so we chose to migrate to AWS when
we made the decision to move we
identified a lot of AWS offerings that
we could use to to migrate cloud
services to but we we really started
focusing on auto scaling groups which
are very similar to what we already knew
about and we were used to it we also
really were excited about Windows
containers and we are really really
really excited to see that Windows
containers are totally supported running
on ECS and the last piece of our

we host many many different databases
and I'm sure a lot of people have very
large sequel server databases here and
we knew that was super critical to the
success of our migration and we needed
some help so we actually worked with AWS
and we found a great AWS certified
partner rellis actually and they
assisted us but we used the data

worked really really fantastically so
I'm gonna talk a little bit about how we
migrated our cloud our cloud service
paas offering and so just just like
Pearson immutable infrastructure is
really important to us and so what we
really wanted to do was make sure that
when we build a version we know what's
out there and there's no skewing on
configuration or anything and so we used
hashing Corp tools like packer and
terraform to create that that immutable
infrastructure for us and so what
happens when when a developer pushes
code to get our CI runs a build
and then creates an ami with Packer and
by the way Packer is an awesome tool for
Windows customers as well one of the
tips that our team found is we want to
push those a.m. eyes into multiple
regions and first we were building an
ami in one region and then copying it
out we found that if we can concurrently
build the a.m. eyes everywhere all at
once
that was way faster so that's an awesome
tip once we created those a.m. eyes we
actually used terraform to deploy
auto-scaling groups with ec2 instances
running those a.m. eyes and we have a
lot of micro services on over a thousand
VMs and in Asscher we actually used the
smallest possible size VM which is an a0
extra small which is pretty similar to a
t2 micro in AWS we actually discovered
that the t2 Nano which is an even
smaller size ran our workloads great and
that ended up becoming a huge cost
savings for us so overall we're really
happy with our auto scaling groups when
we measure the time from when a
developer clicks deploy so we see green
in the load balancer we're seeing four
times faster launch times and most
importantly because of things like the
t2 Nano and other really great AWS
offerings we're seeing a 35% cost
savings thank you guys
